A cutting template for making covers for the 4 sides of your Thing-o-Matic 3D printer. These can be easily made using A4 sheets of printer transparencies (overhead projector sheets) and a standard 2 hole office hole punch.
Covering the sides of your printer is not just an aesthetic feature either, it can help improve print quality by keeping in heat and keeping out draughts.
By helping keep heat within the body of the printer, the time taken to reach printing temperature is slightly reduced and less strain is placed on the heating elements which may help preserve their lifespan.
By helping keep out draughts a more even and consistent temperature can be maintained we can reduce issues associated with uneven cooling such as weak inter layer bonding, cracking, lifting of the base etc. 
This has been crucial in getting consistent results from our printer as the building we are based in is old and occasionally quite breezy.

• Assemble printer in a breezy room and find it doesn't work well
  • Obtain 5 sheets of printer transparencies (A4 is ideal), hole punch, single sided and double sided adhesive tape.
  • Cut and punch holes in transparencies according to attached file
  • Run Tape along both sides of the chamfered (corners cut off) seam to connect the Front Top and Front Bottom Panels
  • Place doublesided tape around the bolt holes cut into the Front Panel Tabs to help it stick to the front of the machine
  • Run a strip of doublesided tape along the top and bottom of the cutouts on the Left and Right sides of your machine.
  • Run a strip of doublesided tape along the left and right of the cutout on the Rear side of your machine.
  • Run a strip of doublesided tape along the top of the Front side of your machine.
  • Remove the following bolts 6x topmost on front panel, 4x to the sides of rear cutout, 2x that bolt into the acrylic panel on the left side & 2x that bolt into the acrylic panel on the left side.
  • Carefully attach panels to all 4 sides using the double-sided tape taking care that the bolt holes line up correctly
  • Carefully attach Front Panel Tabs so that the sharp ends point towards each other and their holes line up with the middle bolt holes
  • Reinsert all bolts
  • Enjoy more consistent print results
    • Optional 1: Remove all but the inner upper corner of the 2 useless rounded square pieces on the top panel so that you can use them along with the punched holes on the bottom front flap to hold it out of your way when you're working inside the machine. Optional 2: Replace one of the sides panel covers with an A4 page holder/document cover to keep some relevant documents (print settings/job list/Operators Manual in place on your printer! Note: If you are having issues opening the 2010 Autocad format .DWG file try the more oldschool .DXF file

description.text:
I've updated the file to V2 with improved cannons and rear. 
One of my favourite film designs created as a personal design challenge over the holidays for testing a new Laser Cutter.
The plans are for 2.8mm material. Scale as required for thicker material.The large one was made with the same plans in 6mm poplar laserply.
The 'Layer' versions have cut and etch lines on separate layers (I think!) #Updated with corrected versions
I'll add some useful build photos when I glue the next model.

Printer:

LaserCutter

Gluing advice The construction is pretty easy but that may just be because I've made a couple of them. Message if you need more instructions. Use a good quality fast drying wood glue.
The Head is a little tricky as the edges do not lie flat against one another. Use the etched guide lines on the legs to get the correct angles. Use the holes in the joints to line up the connections A thick needle will help with this. Cover them with the pop-out circles. The Head can be placed at any angle you want using the pop-out section inside the roof. Detail of the inside of the head. Note the scraps used to help wedge the front cannon in place and the removable/rotatable cross socket that receives the neck 1 - build the body box taking care to align the etched sides as per the photo. You can also get the roof and neck glued at this stage 2 - build the legs. Note the etch marks that help with alignment. 3- cannon, feet and side cannons. Note left hand side cannon now replaced with larger cannon 4- get yourself a cup of tea for this bit. Build it sides and front first, then the back when the rest is dry. Use an elastic band to keep it all together .Note - rear appendage now removed 5 - the V2 version of this cannon is a much better fit and doesn't need the scraps 6- attach the feet using the hole and etch marks for alignment 7- attach the legs and neck to the body and give them time to dry before finally putting the head in place.

Designed completely in Inkscape using a blurry copy of some old blueprints.
Personal design challenge. Allowed myself limited time during holidays and only three prototype cuts.
With more time I'd add some framework inside the head to make gluing simpler.

description.text:
This is a parametric pirate hook I made for my son's birthday party.  It fits the paw of a 4-5 year old very well.
It consists of three prints, the cup for around the hand, the hook, and then the grip and joining piece.  My son really likes it, although the hook is a little primitive.
I've included the SCAD. The cup file is parametric, and while not greatly laid out, it should be easy enough to scale up or down.  Its also relatively tall, and could easily be shortened by a centimeter or two.  The other files are not parametric, because I was in a hurry, but they should be easy enough to adjust.
Simply print all three parts.  Then dry fit the grip, hook and joining bracket.  Then make sure the hook passes through the cup hole.  Finally use glue to assemble the whole thing more permanently.

comments.text:
There is nothing about your model that could be considered 'parametric' !
The more proper term would be 'solid model'.

Notes: The first layer of this is really thin, so I would pay attention to your setting for initial layer height. I have mine set to 0.3mm for this so that way it gets a few passes before moving up.

I printed this with ABS and used ABS slurry to glue them together so I was not really that concerned with possible holes in the print on the first layer.  The slurry would get into it and fill them.
I am going to spraypaint them silver, I think they will look very nice once I do that.  I am also considering acetone smoothing as an experiment.

First look at the Operant Conditioning Chamber: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1226076 A layer height of 0.3 mm with 20% fill density is recommended. No support material is necessary. You will need also the following materials: 1 - 12 VDC Peristaltic pump (https://www.adafruit.com/products/1150). 2 – # 4 x 1/2 in. Metal Flat Phillips Screw. These screws are used to attach the pump to the stand. 1 - 21-gauge needle. It can be removed from a 3 cc syringe. The plastic end of the needle is inserted into the end of the silicon tube of the pump that will be attached to the water tray in the operant chamber. It helps producing a precise drop of water with every operation of the pump DC motor.

the slits are for velcro strap to be slid in, secured by the bolts/screws (or glue). In the end With bolts screwed in, it was perfect for preventing our uke from sliding off the stand (needs a lift and slight twist to take off, and cannot fall off or be knocked off)

description.text: This was designed so that myself and other printrbot play users can fit filament spools that have a small inner diameter on the printrbot play's current spool holder. It clips on and off of the stock spool holder. I highly recommend the clip stl file is printed in Nylon or another semi flexible material, ABS may work although I have not tried it myself. -if You try ABS let me know if it works in the comments. The reason a flexible filament is needed is because you must flex the clip a fair bit to get it to securely fit on the printer.

Since I have already printed a Master Sword and was looking for a stand, I decided to split the original model and fix the geometry of the original Master Sword (the top bezel around the hole was not centered). The sword recess could have been done better but I didn't want to spend the time on this since it should work.
I still need to update the stand and plug so the plug "locks" into the coin bank. I ended up cutting two slots in the bank with my mini files and I added two notches to the plug with my 3d pen (3doodler2.0). This should be fairly simple, I just need to set aside the time for doing this soon.
(I will update my "cut" master sword thing with the .x3g file for printing at the scale to match the stands current scale.
05FEB16- Added Revision 3 of the Master Sword stand .stl file (resized much bigger and hollow with 2mm thick walls for faster printing). Also added a coin-bank version of Revision 3 (slot in back and hole/plug on the bottom)
09FEB16- Uploaded Revision 5 which should be the FINAL revision. Rev3 and Rev 4 were not modeled as best they could so I redesigned these yet again with outstanding results! Sketchup was bugging with the Tri-Force geometry in S3D so that required me to run these thru Netfabb for repairs. The results are great and I am printing the coin bank now. I was about to model the Tri-Force symbol separately from the stand and just print the tri-force model in place but decided to check Netfabb basic(I use the client version).
For those of you NOT using Simplify3d.com software, it will save you tons of time and money...I was able to preview the coin bank model and noticed the extra "solid infil layers" that should not have been there, which would have rendered the coin bank AND letter opener portions of this model useless.
I also included the .x3g file for the Master Sword (1/2 slice) at the proper scale for the stand and coin bank models...I don't remember if I saved the .stl at the scaled size but I basically placed the master sword slice diagonally across my Duplicator 4 print bed so any Replicator clone printer should print the .s3g fine. Oh and I use ABS so you need to adjust the temp if you are using PLA

The full body STL is included if you want to hack it up yourself, but the plate should print well on a Makerbot with full support material.  
The Meshmixer file is included too for further editing.

title: The Evolution of the Mens Ring

description.text: I have seen several ring designs on Thingiverse, Heck the first model I built was a ring that i am still trying to get a printed model. These are the next evolution of my rings. I started with a Ginormous blockey ring. While wearable it looked rather dorkey. Then I created the square head ring which I will eventually make a new version of as it is a very nice looking ring. Finally I came to the smooth rounded rings. These rings are very close to what I am wanting. I am trying to build a ring to replace my old class ring that got broken a long time ago. so here ya go. My next step is going to be to dress up the sides of the ring much more like an actual class ring.

I design all my models in Autocad and as a rule the models will need to be moved to the platform, centered and roatated so that the top is down. They come out quite nice. Enjoy.
I listed a dremel in the tools. I find that a light sanding and polishing via dremel make the ring much more comfortable to wear. It may not be needed if your printer has higher resolution that my Cupcake.

EDIT: Hollowed out for quicker printing, if you don't care to hollow out the scaffold later I suggest closing up the spinal hole

Yet another mutant biomechanical weapon, building on the proven use of sharks as engines from the UW-33. This was designed specifically for anti-submarine warfare, with greater endurance and intelligence due to the incorporation of a giant squid. This is a mashup of the giant squid, reef shark and night fighter from the Autodesk 123D Gallery, all combined in Meshmixer. Update: v8 adds a cockpit greenhouse, and some conical supports for the drop tanks. You still need to print with full support, but the cones keep the tanks from wobbling too much. You should be able to break them off easily.
I've included the full model, and a plate containing the front and back which should print on a Makerbot, using full support material.

This is a slight redesign of the Motorcycle throttle lock by toofuu (thicker, more rigid, with glove friendly chamfers). I added a thumbscrew that works with an M4 bolt/nut to tighten the throttle lock if its grip starts loosening. The thumbscrew is mounted with some interference to keep it from slipping. Use a stainless steel M4 bolt (20mm) and a standard nut. If you are looking for a handguard compatible version, find it here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1329289\ IMPORTANT SAFETY WARNING: make sure that the head of the bolt fits in the hexagonal recess in the bottom rail of the hinge, and is flush with the surface where the brake lever slides. It is dangerous to have any protrusion that might interfere with the brake lever operation. Before you try the throttle lock on the road, familiarize yourself with its operation, adjust the screw tension, make sure nothing interferes with the normal operation of your controls, etc. you don't want to find out something is not working right during a panic brake....

title: Robot figure with flexible joints (parametric, OpenSCAD)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This robot figure uses old fashioned screws to achieve flexible joints, but instead of nuts I prefer to let the screws cut their own threads. This robot was inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:331035.

Prepare all holes for screws The model is designed for M3 screws, but possibly some holes come out too tight.
(This is a problem which many FDM printers have for small holes.)
With a drill enlarge holes where a thread should be cut to a diameter of 2.5 mm.
Where the screw should fit loose use 3 mm. For me (using PLA) no extra tools for cutting the thread were necessary. Otherwise a specific thread cutter might be useful. You can also adjust the screw hole size as parameter in the robot.scad file. (Search for "screw" - related parameters.)

OpenSCAD file "robot.scad" The figure was designed for adjusting. Several parameters at the top section allow simple changes. E.g. the torso-sizes "torsoX", "torsoY", "torsoZ" are used as base parameters from which many other parameters derive. If you e.g. change the "torsoZ" value, then also the arm and leg lengths change proportionally. (See the OpenSCAD-renderings for torsoZ=40, 60 and 30 respectively.) For experimenting you might want to reduce the quality settings "$fn" and "cornerQuality", otherwise rendering will take long. You might also want to put your own text on the robot. Please have a look at
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:96714
on how to create your own font. Would you like something customizable? Let me know.

title: Push Shoe or Push Stick for Table Saw Safety

description.text:
Safety first! This is a push shoe or push stick for use with table saws, routers, etc. Use this instead of your hand to keep your stock flat and flush while preventing injuries. There are four iterations for various needs: -1/2" or 12.7 mm "thin" version is 5 mm thick (pushshoe.50.5.stl)--most versatile and shortest print time
-1/4" or 6.35 mm is 10 mm thick (pushshoe.25.stl)
-1/2" or 12.7 mm is 10 mm thick (pushshoe.50.stl)
-1" or 25.4 mm is 10 mm thick (pushshoe1inch.stl). It's fine to use a smaller version on larger stock, but you may not be able to use a larger version on stock smaller than the vertical clearance. This is intentionally designed small to accommodate smaller printers and will print fine on a 100mm x 100mm bed (4" x 4"). Scale up or down as you like. I assume no responsibility for any damage or injuries that may result when utilizing this thing.

This is a simple radial fan holder for a MK8 extruder. The extruder I have has a not used screw hole at the bottom side next to the extruder. This can be used to mount a fan.
I designed therefore a simple holder to fit a 50 x 50 mm radial fan (Type TFD-B5015M12B ) next to the extruder.
The air is just blown to the heating block. I read in a forum that this works, as enough turbulence should be created. I print with PLA and after mounting this fan, bridges and small pieces work better than before, so I am happy. The shown piece is also in PLA, I did not yet check, whether it would survive the first prints with ABS. There is at least a small hole placed in the most critical part. This is for measuring the temperature in the piece.
Since I have this fan, I use the auto settings from Slic3r. And it really improves certain critical parts while printing in PLA (bridges, ... )
The part is not perfect, some of the air is not guided to the heating block but upwards. This is a design error that I did not correct. Even this design costed me hours of work and two not working test prints. The part here is number 3 and working successfully since a month, so I upload it.
Have fun printing.
11 September 2016 I uploaded the stl again as it was corrupt, sorry for the delay.

I used 123D Design, this made the nice roundings easy to make.
I added the 123 D files in various states of completeness to make tuning the part to other printers easier.

description.text:
This is my own vision of the Vaeder extruder More comming soon !!! This is a work in progress, sorry for the lack of documentation udp 09/03/2016
changed almost every parts.
works now with 18mm height pulleys ( muche common one)
aded a 8mm version of the drive pulley -> better use 8mm axis to get the best pullex allignment. you can find some 20th gt2 pulleys with 8mm bore anywhere on the internet.
this version works fine on 3 prototypes I've made.
Let me know if you have any question or difficulty making this thing work ! (Zapperke ( http://www.thingiverse.com/Zapperke/about ) made a 3mm version, you shall be able to use it in the next release if he gives us his files :) I've also aded a new motor support whitch fits more motors and printers udp 08/01/2016
  • Replaced "chassis2" part, witch was an older version. sorry about that.
  • Replaces "outlet" part, same reason. Added 3 version to adapt the pressfit you already have ( M5 / M6 / M8 )
    • Use std skateboard bearings
    std 20th gt2 pulley
    200 mm / 100 teeth gt2 belts M3 x50 screws 5
    M3 x15 screws     7
    M3 8 headless screws 2
    M3 nuts * 7 bearing x4 nema 17 motor "Bearing spools" must be printed at about 102% to fit on the bearings. First prototype is working well, this is an upgraded version.
    bug may occure, please let me know. Since every printer is different, you may have trouble with tensionning the belt.
    If the belt is to loose, lightly scale up the " quicklock" part ! BOM and french forum : http://talk.smartfri.odns.fr/index.php?topic=794.0

Holes should be re-drilled. Use your drill turning backward, so you just melt the plastic instead off scraping it off.
Be carefull when re-drilling the inlet part. 
Be carefull to reduce the curant on your pollolu, so the motor doesn't heat to much. If the motor gets to hot, the chassis part will bend because of the primary belt tension. -> baaaaad (see picture)
stp/mm are around 425.
Sources are solidworks files, I'll share it if asked.

title: Alpha Decay Model
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This model can be used to demonstrate the alpha decay of a uranium nucleus. Helium nuclei (alpha particles) can be removed from the nucleus. The sizes of the uranium and helium nuclei are approximately to scale. Assuming a simplified decay chain with no beta decays, the model can undergo four alpha decays to reach a stable isotope of lead.
The V2 files have a cutout in the uranium atom so the alpha particles slide inside of the nucleus.

Printer:

Da Vinci Jr.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

5%

Notes: Rafts are recommended for the uranium atom sections to prevent warping of the part if using a non-heated print bed. The uranium atom is separated into two parts to avoid the need for supports. The alpha particle parts should be printed with supports.

If printing the uranium atom in two halves, glue the halves together after printing. Hot glue works well. 
The alpha particles also need to be assembled. Place some glue onto the table on alpha 1, and insert into the cutout in alpha 2. (See picture below).
NGSS CCSS

Nuclear decay is an important part of chemistry and physics curricula. There are a lot of misconceptions that students have surrounding radiation and its effects. This models helps to explain one common form of radioactive decay, alpha decay. Objectives: Students will be able to describe how nuclei decay in order to become more stable. Students will be able to use the law of conservation of mass to predict the identity of the element as alpha particles are given off. Students will be able to describe the relative sizes of atomic nuclei. Preparation:
Students should be familiar with the parts of the atom and the effect of changing the numbers of protons, neutrons, and electrons on the atom type, atomic number, mass number, and charge. Teaching nuclear decay is a good way of having students practice and expand upon these concepts. The model can be used as an introduction to a unit on nuclear decay.

Introduce students to the idea that the nucleus of an atom is only stable with certain ratios of protons and neutrons. Atoms larger than lead undergo alpha decay in order to become more stable. Show the model and remove an alpha particle. Have students determine what element the alpha particle is the same as. (the red spheres are protons while the white spheres are neutrons). Give students the original mass number and atomic numbers for the uranium atom (238 and 92) and have them figure out what the element remains once the alpha particle has left. Repeat until all alpha particles have been ejected and stable lead is formed.
The alpha particles can also be used to model particle radiation. The model can be used to show they are fast moving particles which carry energy.
As an additional exercise, students can use CAD software to design a model that can represent electron capture or beta decay.
A periodic table will be helpful in determining the new atom's identity in the activity along with the model.

description.text:
1:16 scale FDM ABS (black) 3D printed model
Russian heavy tank JS-2 model 1955 ChKZ
This is the turret for the conversion of a Tamiya 1:16 scale KV-1 tank to a JS-2 tank. The upper hull and glacius plate will soon follow.

This part was scanned with NextEngine's 3D laser scanner and ScanStudio HD PRO 1.2 BETA 64 bit, the derived mesh was then turned into a parametric model using RapidWorks (Rapidform's XOR bundled for NextEngine), then the parametric model was saved off as an .STL and sent to CatalystEX to sanity check and create toolpath for the Dimension SST1200 3D printer.

comments.author: ferret7

comments.text: The next time I take the printhead apart I'll photograph it.  The major difference I see between the Stratasys and the RepRap/MakeBot is the later do not have any thermal inertia built into the printhead which makes maintaining the temperature for an even extrusion difficult.  The model material and surrounding air keep removing the heat making it necessary to pause or pulse the feed stock resulting in uneven extrusion.  If you were to insert the heater into a block of dense metal you would have a thermal mass (sort of acts like a capacitor in an electronic circuit evening out the peeks and valleys).  I was also considering making modifications to my printhead (the following is copyrighted 20090815) to lay down a fine wire thread for embedded circuitry right into the FDM model.  I'm working on this design for my tank turrets ( main gun elevation, coaxial laser sight, IR detector, etc...)

description.text:
Remember the last time you went flying with your luggage? You know, the black boxy things that look exactly similar to nearly everyone else's? Off the plane you go, finally glad to have some space only to crowd together with everyone again like a giant brood of starving chickens, just waiting for YOUR luggage to come out the magic portal.
And....there it is! Way over there. Oh, 'scuse me. Pardon. Ouch! Sorry. Ah, don't go back in the portal!! Almost there! Heeeeeaavvee. Wheh, got it!
Oh. :( It's not even yours. Grrr.
Those days are over, friends, thanks to the ingenuity of my glob-trotting coworker, who asked me to print out a big pacman to tie to her bags.  Presto!  Easily identifiable luggage!!

• Download the packman-packman.stl file
  • Print
  • Tie to your luggage with ribbon, rope, chain, etc.
  • Rest easy--now you'll know which bag is yours and don't have to worry about anyone else mistakenly getting it instead. Of course, they might WANT yours more since it's now way cooler than theirs.

title: 92mm fan plate duct for Rostock Max

description.text:
This is a simple side plate for a Rostock Max V2. The idea is to get airflow directed toward the stepper motors and electronics. You can invert the design to fit the plate to the opposite side of the Rostock base and therefore get IN>OUT airflow if you mount your fans accordingly.
The design is specced to accommodate 92mm PC case fans. You should be able to just clip the fan on to the pegs and install.
NOTE: Make sure you use slow speed or 'silent' fans such as 1200rpm, otherwise the amount of airflow will cool your hotbed!

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

5%

Notes: I found that printing at 0.4mm and above results in the fan clips requiring a tiny amount of shaving down to get them to fit. I printed mine at 0.3mm.
Be gentle with the clips! The pegs should slide snugly into the 80mm fan holes. Don't force it as they may snap off.

title: Maze sphere generator
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is based on Maze cylinder generator. It's easy to print. You may change the following parameters to generate a maze sphere, a different maze every time.
  • radius
  • vertical_blocks
  • horizontal_blocks
  • wall_height
  • wall_thickness
  • arm_and_base
  • simple_support_on_the_top
    • Setting both arm_and_base and simple_support_on_the_top as "YES" will generate a simple support structure - eight little blocks - on the top of the sphere. Remember to remove them after printing. Find all my mazes in the collection "maze generators".

• OpenSCAD Documentation - Traditional Chinese
  • OpenSCAD Documentation - English

mElephant

  • Binary tree algorithm
  • Random maze

remixed_from.author: GregFrost
remixed_from.title: Lm8uu X Carriage with Fan Mount for Prusa Mendel

title: Lm8uu X Carriage with Fan Mount for Prusa Mendel

description.text:
Slight change to Greg's excellent x-carriage. 1, I broke at least 2 x-carriages while trying to insert the bearings (I didn't warm up the holders first) So i change the holder design a bit to let the bearings slide in easily, then i added 2 build-in ziptie channels to the holder themselves.
  • Added a belt_socket_offset variable to allow changes to belt-socket alignment. 0 gives Greg's default which fits Prusa's new (felt branch) x-ends nicely. You may want to increase it to something like 10 (guesstimate only) if you are using the original prusa x-ends.
The included STL fits felt branch x-ends.  if you need something different, download the scad files and put them into the same directory as configuration.scad.

description.text:
Yet another in my line of odd things that probably won't be of any use to anyone but me!  
This mounts on the wall and lets me hang up a big two-cup ladle and a funnel mostly horizontally to fit into the small space below the cupboard.  
I use these when mixing up my own SodaStream syrup (3 parts Diet Pepsi from a five-gallon bag-in-box, 1 part Da Vinci sugar-free cherry syrup) in my utility room on the counter in a big plastic bin.  This rack will keep the parts handy.  
There's a big groove in which the handle hangs the ladle at an angle of about 30 degrees, with the hook holding it in place.  There's a big amount of space to hold the ladle handle away from the wall, since the ladle cup obviously sticks out from the sides of the handle.  Below this, the funnel hangs on a hook.  All in all, a clever use of space, if I do say so myself.  
This is my first time making conical countersink screw-holes.  I'm happy with how it worked out.
This should print pretty simply without supports, and not need a lot of infill.  I did need to throw in a brim to keep it from curling.

title: Lasercutter Raster/Vector Settings Checker + Kerf Tester

description.text:
Makes it easy to test and dial in your raster and vector mode settings when working with new materials or thicknesses on the laser cutter. It's also easy with this design to check the kerf (the amount of material that the laser removes in a cut) by slinging a caliper either inside the quarter-inch hole or on the quarter-inch tab, both of which are supposed to be exactly 1/4".
The deviation from 1/4" represents 2x the kerf value, which has a slight bonus of making a more accurate figure from, if you're like me, your probably-not-so-stellar calipers. Once you have an idea of the kerf your laser cutter and your settings create, you can then resize things like box joinery in your designs in order to have exact snap-fits with each other, right out of the cutter!

This is a tray for 12 50mm bottles to be laser-cut from two kinds of 3mm acrylic.  
It uses no glue, screws or any other parts.

Preparation:

  • Check that you're using a material with the correct thickness. Otherwise you'll have to rework all 3mm slots.

  • Use the "top" file to cut the parts that are clear acrylic in my pictures. Use the "bottom" file for the black parts. If you'r printer does not ignore the orange part of the drawing, delete them first!

  • Most slots have some bumps in them that allow for machining tolerances. Check them with a piece of the target material (check assembly instructions to see which slots take which color material). You will find that it won't quite fit. That is normal. Use a fine file to file the bumps down until there slots are just tight. Don't force the pieces into the slots---this will result in cracks.
    • To assemble:

  • Identify the upper (w/ holes) and lower (w/o holes) tray boards, the inner (2 slots) and outer (2 cutouts) handles, and 2 (identical) stabilization strips.

  • Slide both tray boards into their slots of both inner handles.

  • Put both stabilization strips into their little slots beneath the lower tray. Note: These will bend a little after assembly. This is intended.

  • Slide the outer handles in from the top. This will lock the whole thing in place.

  • You're done.

description.text: Took Claud10's headphone mount and modified for my desk.  The main changes are increasing grip size, lengthing the upper and lower support arms and lengthening the hanging bracket to hold my headphones, (which have a large band HyperX Cloud II.)  I have included my updated stl export and the modified sketchup file.

Printer:

Da Vinci

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

20%

Notes: i did 20% infill for increased stiffness

Those last few meters of filament on small-diameter rolls drive me nuts! Coiled so tightly I can barely get it off by hand, it always causes problems for my printer. Tired of trying to uncoil and straighten those tight little loops by hand, I created this Filament Straightener. It is, obviously, modeled on wire straighteners, but uses printed parts and is sized for filament. Pictures show before and after of tightly coiled filament. The after was put back on a reel for easy printing and worked great! This design was done using FreeCAD. As an experienced OpenSCAD user, I find FreeCAD a very satisfactory alternative that I am choosing more and more often for new designs. The FreeCAD files are included; STEP format files are also included. This is similar to, but not derived from, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30733 .

Bill of Materials
One of each of the stls. I used PLA with 40% infill.
3 ea. 608 bearings.
3 ea. 5/16 x 1 1/2in.Ã‚Â€Ã‚Â or M8 x 40mm bolts.
6 ea. matching washers.
3 ea. matching nuts.
6 ea. #6 x1 1/4in.Ã‚Â€Ã‚Â sheet metal screws (not sure of the metric for these?).
1 ea. #10 x 2in.Ã‚Â€Ã‚Â, or M5 x 50mm screw (all thread if possible).
2 ea. matching bolts.
Base for mounting. I used 1/2in.Ã‚Â€Ã‚Â plywood that I had on hand. Needs to be big enough to clamp or hold while filament is being straightened. Use the straightener body as a template to mark locations of the heads of the two large bolts. Drill the holes with a diameter and depth to provide clearance for the heads. (Not critical.) With the body in the same position, mark the groove needed for the bolt head on the slider. Allow a little extra on each side to clear the head and use a coping saw or saber saw to cut the groove. (Not critical. Mark the holes for the four body mounting screws and drill pilot holes if needed. Put one of the bolts through the body, put a washer on it, then a bearing, another washer, and the nut. Tighten the nut firmly. Repeat for the other body bolt and the slider bolt. Put the slider into the slot in the body and secure the body to your base using four of the screws. Press a nut for the long screw into the pocket in the tensioner and thread the long screw through it. Put the other nut on. This is a lock nut to keep the tension constant. Position the tensioner a small distance from the body (about the width of the lock nut or so) and use the last two sheet metal screws to anchor it. Your straightener is ready to use. To use your straightener, put the end of the filament to be straightened between the bearings as shown in the photo. Tighten the tensioner bolt as desired, then pull the filament through. Adjust until you get the desired result. If a significant straightening is desired, often it is better to do it in a few steps using multiple passes, rather than trying to do it all at once.

title: Malayan tapir -- moore
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Created this because it looks funny. My girlfriend likes this so I named it Moore. you can turn this into a necklace. -------HOW TO PRINT --------
This requires a simple and easy technique for the black and white effect. ==Start the print on your printer, write down how many layers your printer will take to print this (2mm thickness shows 6 layers with a 0.25 resolution on my Up!Plus) ==Let the printer print till 3rd layer ( half way of the print 6/2 = 3.), stop feeding by cutting out the black filament == As the remaining black filament is being printed, feed the white filament in. So the printer will run out of white and start printing with black. PS:You will need to have similar printing temperature filaments.

description.text:

Anyway enjoy my work!!!!

Parts for a RepRap Prusa i3 mount using a load cell for Z-probing. The electronics attaches to the back mount, and the extruder to the front mount. The files are designed with a stepper motor mounted extruder/hot end, like the Geeetech Mk8. The six tabs on the cooler duct are just to improve adhesion to the bed while printing. They are snapped off after printing. See my instructable for more details on construction and calibration http://www.instructables.com/id/Reprap-Load-Cell-Z-Probe/ Firmware files are at https://github.com/palmerr23/LoadCell_ZProbe

comments.text: The Sanguinololu electronics is a really neat piece of all-in-one electronics. However, it is a bit limited with extra pins for expansion. You shouldn't have too much difficulty sourcing the power supply voltages, but there don't seem to be convenient headers on the S. board for that either.

author: didwlsch

title: Clamp hooks for a 15.5mm (5/8") diameter rail

description.text:
We have an Ikea wall mounted dish drainer. The wall mounting is a long rail from which the dish drainer hangs and a lot of left over rail and S shaped hooks so that cups, or strainers, etc can be suspended from the rail.
I found the supplied hooks (S-shaped Stainless Steel) annoying as they were a very loose fit and easily moved out of position when casually hanging something from them. I wanted hooks that 'held their position' and didn't require so much concentration - or hand eye coordination.
Hence these hooks. The slighter one requires only one M3 screw, but requires partial disassembly of the rail, the other does not require any disassembly but requires 2 M3 x 10mm long screws. (I use stainless steel button head cap screws.)
The slighter one can only carry light articles. I recommend lighter than 250gms. There's no science behind this figure but I do know that this hook will not support a mug weighing 370gm long term. Looks fine to start with but the hook fails (where the handle of the mug rests) after approx one year. However it seems OK carrying a strainer which weights about 220gms.
Hence the more rugged hook. Hopefully this will hold the mug 'forever'.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker Original

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes: Actually I used the Ultimaker to make the slighter hooks in PLA and a Robox to make the sturdier hooks in ABS.
If the Ultimaker has been available I'd have made the sturdier hooks on in in PLA.
Designed in Moment of Inspiration (MOI).

author: chrismolloy

title: Sweeper weight in coins for B9Creator
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This sweeper weight can be conveniently loaded with coins.
Its centre of gravity is located right over the sweeper to allow maximum stability when the Vat moves. Below the link explaining why this accessory can be useful in prolonging the life of the coating. :
http://b9creator.com/support/?mingleforumaction=viewtopic&t=485 The advised weight is about 20 to 30 grams for each of the two sides: that is about half of the maximum number of coins. Use the same weight for both sides. If you prefer not to use the springs, you can, but fill the container with coins. Fitting coins include:
  • one UK pence,
  • 10 Euro cents, and
  • one US dime (I haven't tested the dime but it is smaller than the other coins).
    • The cap locks with a little snap. To limit resin consumption, the item is a bit fragile: I haven't had breakage issues (I use a very strong resin) but take care or ask me to thicken some features. Let me know if you have suggestions, or you need the shape modified to fit coins from other countries or you need to hold more weight.
You can slice at 50xy, as the design fits the smallest envelope.

comments.text: hi Gavi, still happy with the results??? does is really help …?
comments.author: juweeltje

comments.text:
Hi!
Yes, it works very well and it helps in removing the resin and letting the coating breath better. You have to find the right amount of coins. Half the capacity is the good place to start.

Some steps might be required to assemble 1) You may use sanding paper or a steel file to shape gears a little so they rotate smoothly
2) When you put it together, make sure that the top is fit firmly to rods, then heat a little rod ends and apply it to a smooth surface gently so rods will fuse with the top.

This is a mount I remixed so that the FR632 receiver can be screwed onto the top of a lighting tripod used in photography. These can be found on ebay for around $20.
The helical mount was removed from the front and an insert has been added so that a nut for a 1/4" thread can be used to screw the mount onto the tripod tightly.
